hypotheses: Hypnopompic heart rate variability (HRV) can assist in the prediction of cardiovascular disease (CVD) outcomes.
Entropy-based indices of HRV have greater predictive power than conventional HRV measures.
HRV measures contribute to better short-term prediction accuracy of CVD events compared to long-term prediction.

experiment_details.participant_criteria: Baseline CVD-free students divided into CVD and non-CVD groups.

results_summary.contribution_of_HRV: HRV metrics, especially entropy-based indices, contributed significantly to prediction
results_summary.importance_of_HRV_metrics: More important for short-term CVD prediction than long-term outcomes

conclusion.hypotheses_verification: Hypotheses are supported, demonstrating HRV's utility in predicting CVD, especially short-term outcomes.
conclusion.suggestions: Incorporating hypnopompic HRV and entropy-based measures into CVD risk evaluation models.
